ai-an8:1.2.1_0: “Mendicants, you can expect eight benefits when the heart’s release by love has been cultivated, developed, and practiced, made a vehicle and a basis, kept up, consolidated, and properly implemented.
ai-an8:1.2.2_0: What are the teachings grouped by eight?
ai-an8:1.2.3_0: You sleep at ease. You wake happily. You don’t see bad dreams. Humans love you. Non-humans love you. Deities protect you. You can’t be harmed by fire, poison, or blade. If you don’t reach any higher, you’ll be reborn in a Brahmā realm.
ai-an8:1.2.4_0: You can expect these eight benefits when the heart’s release by love has been cultivated, developed, and practiced, made a vehicle and a basis, kept up, consolidated, and properly implemented.
ai-an8:1.4.1_0: Loving just one creature with a hateless heart
ai-an8:1.4.4_0: a noble one creates abundant merit.
ai-an8:1.5.1_0: The royal potentates conquered this land
ai-an8:1.5.2_0: (There is) no way I will roam about,
ai-an8:1.5.4_0: the sacrifices of the ‘stick-casting’, the ‘royal soma drinking’, and the ‘unbarred’.
ai-an8:1.6.1_0: These are not worth a sixteenth part
ai-an8:1.6.2_0: of the mind developed with love,
ai-an8:1.6.3_0: as starlight cannot rival the moon.
ai-an8:1.6.4_0: Just as a plantain burns from log
ai-an8:1.7.1_0: not killing or causing others to kill:
ai-an8:1.7.2_0: don’t conquer or encourage others to conquer,
ai-an8:1.7.3_0: with love for all sentient beings,
ai-an8:1.7.4_0: you’ll have no enmity for anyone.”
ai-an8:2.1.1_0: “Mendicants, there are eight causes and reasons that lead to acquiring the wisdom fundamental to the spiritual life, and to its increase, growth, and full development once it has been acquired.
ai-an8:2.1.2_0: What are the teachings grouped by eight?
ai-an8:2.1.3_0: It’s when a mendicant lives relying on the Teacher or a spiritual companion in a teacher’s role. And they set up a keen sense of conscience and prudence for them, with warmth and respect.
ai-an8:2.2.1_0: When a mendicant lives relying on the Teacher or a spiritual companion in a teacher’s role—with a keen sense of conscience and prudence for them, with warmth and respect—from time to time they go and ask them questions:
ai-an8:2.2.2_0: ‘Why, sir, does it say this? What does that mean?’
ai-an8:2.2.3_0: Those venerables clarify what is unclear, reveal what is obscure, and dispel doubt regarding the many doubtful matters.
ai-an8:2.3.1_0: After hearing that teaching they perfect withdrawal of both body and mind.
ai-an8:2.4.1_0: He is virtuous and restrained by the Monastic Code. His conduct is good, he associates with the right people, and he sees danger in minor faults. And he undertakes and trains in the training rules.
ai-an8:2.5.1_0: They’re very learned, remembering and keeping what they’ve learned.
ai-an8:2.6.1_0: They live with energy roused up for giving up unskillful qualities and embracing skillful qualities. They’re strong, staunchly vigorous, not slacking off when it comes to developing skillful qualities.
ai-an8:2.7.1_0: When in the Saṅgha they don’t engage in motley talk or unworthy talk.
ai-an8:2.7.2_0: Either they talk on Dhamma, or they invite someone else to do so, or they respect noble silence.

ai-an8:3.1.1_0: “Mendicants, a mendicant with eight qualities is disliked and disapproved by their spiritual companions, not respected or admired.
ai-an8:3.1.3_0: It’s when a mendicant praises the disliked and criticizes the liked. They desire material possessions and honor. They lack conscience and prudence. They have wicked desires and wrong view.
ai-an8:3.1.4_0: A mendicant with these eight qualities is disliked and disapproved by their spiritual companions, not respected or admired.
ai-an8:3.2.1_0: A mendicant with eight qualities is liked and approved by their spiritual companions, respected and admired.
ai-an8:3.2.3_0: It’s when a mendicant doesn’t praise the disliked and criticize the liked. They don’t desire material possessions and honor. They have conscience and prudence. They have few desires and right view.
ai-an8:3.2.4_0: A mendicant with these eight qualities is liked and approved by their spiritual companions, and respected and admired.”
ai-an8:4.1.1_0: “Mendicants, a mendicant with eight qualities is disliked and disapproved by their spiritual companions, not respected or admired.
ai-an8:4.1.3_0: It’s when a mendicant desires material possessions, honor, and to be looked up to. They don’t abuse and insult, attack, encourage others to do the same.

ai-an8:4.2.4_0: A mendicant with these eight qualities is liked and approved by their spiritual companions, and respected and admired.”
ai-an8:5.1.1_0: “Mendicants, the eight worldly conditions revolve around the world, and the world revolves around the eight worldly conditions.
ai-an8:5.1.2_0: What are the teachings grouped by eight?
ai-an8:5.1.3_0: gain and loss, fame and disgrace, praise and blame, pleasure and pain.
ai-an8:5.1.4_0: These eight worldly conditions revolve around the world, and the world revolves around these eight worldly conditions.
ai-an8:5.2.1_0: Gain and loss, fame and disgrace,
ai-an8:5.2.2_0: praise and blame, and pleasure and pain.
ai-an8:5.2.3_0: These qualities among people are impermanent,
ai-an8:5.3.1_0: A clever and mindful person knows these things,
ai-an8:5.3.4_0: nor are they repelled by the undesirable.
ai-an8:5.4.2_0: cleared them and ended them, there is no dart.
ai-an8:5.4.4_0: they understand rightly, going beyond rebirth.”

ai-an8:8.6.6_0: “Sir, they should reply that they took it from the large heap of grain.”

ai-an8:8.6.8_0: Both myself and others rely completely on that when we speak.”

ai-an8:9.4.2_0: Nanda practices walking and sitting meditation by day, purifying his mind from obstacles.
ai-an8:9.4.3_0: In the evening, they continue to practice walking and sitting meditation.
ai-an8:9.4.4_0: In the middle of the night, they lie down in the lion’s posture—on the right side, placing one foot on top of the other—mindful and aware, and focused on the time of getting up.

ai-an8:9.4.6_0: This is how Nanda is committed to wakefulness.

ai-an8:11.1.2_0: At one time the Buddha was staying in Verañja at the root of a neem tree dedicated to Naḷeru.
ai-an8:11.1.3_0: Then the brahmin Verañja went up to the Buddha, and exchanged greetings with him.
ai-an8:11.1.4_0: and after exchanging courteous talk and greetings, he sat down on one side.
ai-an8:11.2.2_0: that you don’t bow down to old brahmins, stand up for them, or offer them a seat.
ai-an8:11.2.3_0: And this is indeed the case,
ai-an8:11.2.4_0: for Master Gotama does not bow to old brahmins, elderly and senior, who are advanced in years and have reached the final stage of life; nor does he rise in their presence or offer them a seat.
ai-an8:11.2.6_0: “Brahmin, I don’t see anyone in this world—with its gods, Māras, and Brahmās, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, its gods and humans—for whom I should bow down or rise up or offer a seat.
ai-an8:11.2.7_0: For if he does bow to him, rise in his presence, or offer him a seat.”
ai-an8:11.3.2_0: “There is, brahmin, a sense in which you could rightly say that
ai-an8:11.3.4_0: For the Realized One has given up taste for sights, sounds, smells, tastes, and touches. It’s cut off at the root, made like a palm stump, obliterated, and unable to arise in the future.
ai-an8:11.3.5_0: In this sense you could rightly say that I’m a teacher of inaction.
ai-an8:11.3.6_0: But that’s not what you’re talking about.”

ai-an8:11.4.4_0: For the liking of forms, sounds, smells, flavors, and material objects has been abandoned by the Buddha, cut off at the root, made like a palm-stump, so utterly done away with that it is incapable of reappearing.
ai-an8:11.4.5_0: In this sense you could rightly say that I’m a teacher of inaction.
ai-an8:11.4.6_0: But that’s not what you’re talking about.”

ai-an8:11.5.5_0: In this sense you could rightly say that I’m a teacher of inaction.
ai-an8:11.5.6_0: But that’s not what you’re talking about.”

ai-an8:11.6.4_1: I speak of the annihilation of various sorts of bad, unwholesome qualities.
ai-an8:11.6.5_0: In this sense you could rightly say that I’m a teacher of inaction.
ai-an8:11.6.6_0: But that’s not what you’re talking about.”

ai-an8:11.7.5_0: In this sense you could rightly say that I’m a teacher of inaction.
ai-an8:11.7.6_0: But that’s not what you’re talking about.”

ai-an8:11.8.6_0: But that’s not what you’re talking about.”

ai-an8:11.9.4_0: For I say that bad, unwholesome qualities—misconduct by body, speech, and mind—are to be disciplined.
ai-an8:11.9.5_0: I say that a mortifier is someone who has given up unskillful qualities that should be mortified. They’ve cut them off at the root, made them like a palm stump, obliterated them, so that they’re unable to arise in the future.
ai-an8:11.9.6_0: The Realized One is someone who has given up unskillful qualities that should be mortified. He has cut them off at the root, made them like a palm stump, obliterated them, so that they’re unable to arise in the future.
ai-an8:11.9.7_0: In this sense you could rightly say that I’m a teacher of inaction.
ai-an8:11.9.8_0: But that’s not what you’re talking about.”

ai-an8:11.10.4_0: I say that an abortionist is someone who has given up future wombs and rebirth into a new state of existence. They’ve cut them off at the root, made them like a palm stump, obliterated them, so that they’re unable to arise in the future.
ai-an8:11.10.5_0: Now my future conception in a womb, my rebirth in a future life, has been abandoned and cut off at the root, made like a palm-stump, so utterly done away with that I’m incapable of reappearing.
ai-an8:11.10.6_0: In this sense you could rightly say that I’m a teacher of inaction.
ai-an8:11.10.7_0: But that’s not what you’re talking about.
ai-an8:11.11.1_0: Brahmin, suppose there were a hen with eight or ten or twelve eggs,
ai-an8:11.11.2_0: And she properly sat on them to keep them warm and incubated.
ai-an8:11.11.3_0: Now, the chick that is first to break out of the eggshell with its claws and beak and hatch safely:
ai-an8:11.11.3_1: should that be called the eldest or the youngest?”
ai-an8:11.11.4_0: “Master Gotama, that should be called the eldest.”
ai-an8:11.12.1_0: “In the same way, in this population lost in ignorance, trapped in their shells, I alone have broken open the egg of ignorance and realized the supreme perfect awakening.
ai-an8:11.12.2_0: For I, brahmin, is the greatest of the world,
ai-an8:11.13.1_0: I was firmly energetic and had clarity of mindfulness; my body was tranquil and my mind unified.
ai-an8:11.13.2_0: Quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, I entered and remained in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.
ai-an8:11.13.4_0: And with the fading away of rapture, I meditate equanimous, mindful, and aware, experiencing bliss directly, and I entered and remained in the third absorption of which the noble ones declare:
ai-an8:11.13.4_1: ‘One is even-minded, mindful, and abides in bliss.’
ai-an8:11.13.5_0: With the giving up of pleasure and pain, and the ending of former happiness and sadness, I enter and remain in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness.
ai-an8:11.14.1_0: When my mind had immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—I extended it toward recollection of past lives.
ai-an8:11.14.2_0: I recollected many kinds of past lives. That is:
ai-an8:11.14.2_1: ʻThere I had such a name, such a family, such appearance, such food, such experience of happiness and suffering, and such a life-span.
ai-an8:11.14.2_2: passing away from there I arose in another state of existence,
ai-an8:11.14.2_3: and there I had such a name, such a family, such appearance, such food, such experience of happiness and suffering, and such a life-span.
ai-an8:11.14.2_4: When I passed away from that place I was reborn somewhere else.
ai-an8:11.14.2_5: I remember: ‘There, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn somewhere else. There, too, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn here.’ And so I recollect my many kinds of past lives, with features and details.
ai-an8:11.15.1_0: This was the first true insight attained by me in the first part of the night.
ai-an8:11.15.2_0: Ignorance was dispelled and knowledge arose.
ai-an8:11.15.2_1: darkness was destroyed and light arose, as happens for a meditator who is diligent, keen, and resolute.
ai-an8:11.15.3_0: This was my first breaking out, like a chick breaking out of the eggshell.
ai-an8:11.16.1_0: When my mind had immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—I extended it toward knowledge of the death and rebirth of sentient beings.
ai-an8:11.16.2_0: With clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, I saw sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. I understood how sentient beings are reborn according to their deeds:
ai-an8:11.16.2_1: ‘These dear beings did bad things by way of body, speech, and mind.
ai-an8:11.16.2_2: They spoke ill of the noble ones; they had wrong view; and they chose to act out of that wrong view.
ai-an8:11.16.2_3: When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.
ai-an8:11.16.2_4: at the breaking up of the body after death, have been reborn in a good destination, a heaven world.’
ai-an8:11.16.2_5: They never spoke ill of the noble ones; they had right view; and they acted out of that right view. When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.’ And so, with clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, I saw sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. I understood how sentient beings are reborn according to their deeds.
ai-an8:11.17.1_0: This was the second knowledge, which I achieved in the middle watch of the night.
ai-an8:11.17.2_0: Ignorance was dispelled and knowledge arose.
ai-an8:11.17.2_1: darkness was destroyed and light arose, as happens for a meditator who is diligent, keen, and resolute.
ai-an8:11.17.3_0: This was my second breaking out, like a chick breaking out of the eggshell.
ai-an8:11.18.1_0: When my mind had become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—I extended it toward knowledge of the ending of defilements.
ai-an8:11.18.2_0: I truly understood: ‘This is suffering’ ... ‘This is the origin of suffering’ ... ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ ... ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.'
ai-an8:11.18.3_0: I truly understood: ‘These are defilements’ ... ‘This is the origin of defilements’ ... ‘This is the cessation of defilements’ ... ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of defilements’.
ai-an8:11.18.4_0: Knowing and seeing like this, my mind was freed from the defilements of sensuality, desire to be reborn, and ignorance.
ai-an8:11.18.5_0: When it was freed, I knew it was freed.
ai-an8:11.18.6_0: I understood: ‘Rebirth is ended; the spiritual journey has been completed; what had to be done has been done; there is no return to any state of existence.’
ai-an8:11.19.1_0: This was the third knowledge, which I achieved in the last watch of the night.
ai-an8:11.19.2_0: Ignorance was dispelled and knowledge arose.
ai-an8:11.19.2_1: darkness was destroyed and light arose, as happens for a meditator who is diligent, keen, and resolute.
ai-an8:11.19.3_0: This was my third breaking out, like a chick breaking out of the eggshell.”
ai-an8:11.20.1_0: When he said this, the brahmin Verañja said to the Buddha:
ai-an8:11.20.2_0: “Master Gotama is the eldest! Master Gotama is the best!
ai-an8:11.20.4_0: Just as one might set upright what had been overturned, or reveal what had been hidden, or show the way to one who was lost, or bring a lamp into the darkness so that
ai-an8:11.20.4_1: so that one with eyes might see what’s there—
ai-an8:11.20.4_2: just so has the Dhamma been explained by the dear Gotama in countless ways.
ai-an8:11.20.5_0: Good Gotama, I go for refuge to you, and to the Teaching and to the Sangha of monks.
ai-an8:11.20.6_0: From this day forth, may Master Gotama remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”
ai-an8:12.1.1_0: At one time the Buddha was staying near Vesālī, at the Great Wood, in the hall with the peaked roof.
ai-an8:12.1.2_0: Now at that time several very prominent Licchavis were sitting together at the meeting hall, praising the Buddha, his teaching, and the Saṅgha in many ways.
ai-an8:12.2.1_0: Now at that time General Sīha, a disciple of the Jains, was sitting in that assembly.

ai-an8:12.2.5_1: and after approaching he said this to the Nigaṇṭha Nātaputta:
ai-an8:12.2.6_0: “Sir, I wish to visit the ascetic Gotama.”

ai-an8:12.25.1_0: When he said this, General Sīha said to the Buddha,
ai-an8:12.25.3_0: From this day forth, may the Buddha remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”
ai-an8:12.26.1_0: “Consider it carefully, Sīha. It’s good for well-known people such as yourself to think carefully.”
ai-an8:12.26.2_0: “Now I’m even more delighted and satisfied with the Buddha, since he tells me to
ai-an8:12.26.2_1: ‘Sīha, you should act after careful consideration.
ai-an8:12.26.2_2: It’s good for well-known people such as yourself to think carefully.’
ai-an8:12.26.3_0: For if the followers of other paths were to gain me as a disciple, they’d carry a banner all over Vesālī, saying:
ai-an8:12.26.5_1: ‘Sīha, you should act after careful consideration.
ai-an8:12.26.5_2: It’s good for well-known people such as yourself to think carefully.’
ai-an8:12.26.6_0: For the second time I go for refuge to you and to the Teaching and to the Sangha of monks.
ai-an8:12.26.7_0: From this day forth, may the Buddha remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”
ai-an8:12.27.1_0: “For a long time now, Sīha, your family has been a well-spring of support for the Jain ascetics. You should consider giving to them when they come.”
ai-an8:12.27.2_0: “Now I’m even more delighted and satisfied with the Buddha, since he tells me to
ai-an8:12.27.3_0: consider giving to the Jain ascetics when they come.
ai-an8:12.27.6_0: “Gifts should only be given to me, and to my disciples.
ai-an8:12.27.7_0: Only what is given to me is very fruitful, not what is given to others.
ai-an8:12.27.8_0: Only what is given to my disciples is very fruitful, not what is given to the disciples of others.”’
ai-an8:12.27.9_0: But in reality you encourage me to give to the Jains.
ai-an8:12.27.10_0: Indeed, I shall know the right time for this.
ai-an8:12.27.11_0: For the third time I go for refuge to you and to the Teaching and to the Sangha of monks.
ai-an8:12.27.12_0: From this day forth, may the Buddha remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”
ai-an8:12.28.1_0: Then the Buddha taught Sīha step by step, with
ai-an8:12.28.2_0: talk on generosity, talk on morality, talk on heaven; and he revealed the danger, degradation, and defilement in worldly pleasures, and the benefit of renunciation.
ai-an8:12.28.3_0: And when the Buddha knew that Sīha’s mind was ready, pliable, rid of hindrances, joyful, and confident he explained the special teaching of the Buddhas:
ai-an8:12.28.4_0: suffering, its origin, its cessation, and the path.
ai-an8:12.28.5_0: Just as a clean cloth rid of stains would properly absorb dye,
ai-an8:12.28.6_0: in that very seat the stainless, immaculate vision of the Dhamma in that very seat:
ai-an8:12.28.7_0: “Anything that has a beginning has an end.”
ai-an8:12.29.1_0: Then Sīha saw, attained, understood, and fathomed the Dhamma. He went beyond doubt, got rid of indecision, and became self-assured and independent of others regarding the Teacher’s instructions. He said to the Buddha,
ai-an8:12.29.2_0: “Venerable Sir, please accept a meal from me tomorrow together with the Sangha of monks.”
ai-an8:12.29.3_0: The Buddha consented by remaining silent.
ai-an8:12.29.4_0: Knowing that the Buddha had consented, Sīha got up from his seat, bowed down, circumambulated the Buddha with his right side toward him, and left.
ai-an8:12.30.2_0: “Mister, please find out if there is any meat ready for sale.”
ai-an8:12.30.3_0: And when the night had passed Sīha had a variety of delicious foods prepared in his own home. Then he had the Buddha informed of the time, saying,
ai-an8:12.31.1_0: Then the Buddha robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, went to Sīha’s home.
ai-an8:12.31.1_1: and after approaching he sat down on the prepared seat, together with the Community of monks.
ai-an8:12.31.2_0: Now at that time many Jain ascetics in Vesālī went from street to street and square to square, calling out with raised arms:
ai-an8:12.31.3_0: “Today General Sīha has slaughtered a fat calf for the ascetic Gotama’s meal.
ai-an8:12.31.4_0: The ascetic Gotama knowingly eats meat prepared specially for him: this is a deed he caused.”
ai-an8:12.32.1_0: Then a certain person went to General Sīha,
ai-an8:12.32.1_1: and after approaching he informed Sīha the General Sīha,
ai-an8:12.32.3_0: Many Jain ascetics in Vesālī are going from street to street and square to square, calling out with raised arms:
ai-an8:12.32.4_0: ‘Today General Sīha has slaughtered a fat calf for the ascetic Gotama’s meal.
ai-an8:12.32.5_0: The ascetic Gotama knowingly eats meat prepared specially for him: this is a deed he caused.’
ai-an8:12.32.6_0: “Enough, sir. For a long time those venerables have wanted to discredit the Buddha, his teaching, and his Saṅgha.
ai-an8:12.32.7_0: They’ll never stop misrepresenting the Buddha with their false, hollow, lying, untruthful claims.
ai-an8:12.32.8_0: We would never deliberately take the life of a living creature, not even for life’s sake.”
ai-an8:12.33.1_0: Then Sīha served and satisfied the mendicant Saṅgha headed by the Buddha with his own hands with a variety of delicious foods.
ai-an8:12.33.2_0: When the Buddha had eaten and washed his hand and bowl, Sīha sat down to one side.
ai-an8:12.33.3_0: Then the Buddha educated, encouraged, fired up, and inspired him with a Dhamma talk, after which he got up from his seat and left.

ai-an8:13.2.1_1: they are an unsurpassed field of merit for the world.

ai-an8:13.2.19_0: A mendicant with these eight factors is worthy of offerings dedicated to the gods, worthy of hospitality, worthy of a religious donation, worthy of veneration with joined palms, and is the supreme field of merit for the world.

ai-an8:14.1.1_0: “Mendicants, I will teach you about eight wild colts and eight defects in horses, and about eight wild people and eight defects in people.
ai-an8:14.1.2_0: Listen and pay close attention, I will speak.”
ai-an8:14.2.1_0: “And what, mendicants, are the eight wild colts and eight defects in horses?
ai-an8:14.2.2_0: Firstly, when the trainer says ‘giddyup!’ and spurs and goads them on, some wild colts back right up and spin the chariot behind them.
ai-an8:14.2.3_0: Some wild colts are like that.
ai-an8:14.2.4_0: This is the first defect of a horse.
ai-an8:14.3.1_0: Furthermore, when the trainer says ‘giddyup!’ and spurs and goads them on, some wild colts jump back, wreck the hub, and break the triple rod.
ai-an8:14.3.2_0: Some wild colts are like that.
ai-an8:14.3.3_0: This is the second defect of a horse.
ai-an8:14.4.1_0: Furthermore, when the trainer says ‘giddyup!’ and spurs and goads them on, some wild colts shake the cart-pole off their thigh and trample it.
ai-an8:14.4.2_0: Some wild colts are like that.
ai-an8:14.4.3_0: This is the third defect of a horse.
ai-an8:14.5.1_0: Furthermore, when the trainer says ‘giddyup!’ and spurs and goads them on, some wild colts take a wrong turn, sending the chariot off track.
ai-an8:14.5.2_0: Some wild colts are like that.
ai-an8:14.5.3_0: This is the fourth defect of a horse.
ai-an8:14.6.1_0: Furthermore, when the trainer says ‘giddyup!’ and spurs and goads them on, some wild colts take their fore-legs and goads on, rear up and strike out with their fore-legs.
ai-an8:14.6.2_0: Some wild colts are like that.
ai-an8:14.6.3_0: This is the fifth defect of a horse.
ai-an8:14.7.1_0: Furthermore, when the trainer says ‘giddyup!’ and spurs and goads them on, some wild colts ignore the trainer and the goad, spit out the bit, and go wherever they want.
ai-an8:14.7.2_0: Some wild colts are like that.
ai-an8:14.7.3_0: This is the sixth defect of a horse.
ai-an8:14.8.1_0: Furthermore, when the trainer says ‘giddyup!’ and spurs and goads them on, some wild colts don’t step forward or turn back but stand right there still as a post.
ai-an8:14.8.2_0: Some wild colts are like that.
ai-an8:14.8.3_0: This is the seventh defect of a horse.
ai-an8:14.9.1_0: Furthermore, when the trainer says ‘giddyup!’ and spurs and goads them on, some wild colts tuck in their fore-legs and hind-legs, and sit right down on their four legs.
ai-an8:14.9.2_0: Some wild colts are like that.
ai-an8:14.9.3_0: This is the eighth defect of a horse.
ai-an8:14.9.4_0: These are the eight wild colts and the eight defects in horses.
ai-an8:14.10.1_0: And what are the eight wild people and eight defects in people?
ai-an8:14.10.2_0: Firstly, the mendicants accuse a mendicant of an offense.
ai-an8:14.10.3_0: But the accused mendicant evades it by saying they don’t remember.
ai-an8:14.10.4_0: I say that this person is comparable to the wild colts who, when the trainer says ‘giddyup!’ and spurs and goads them on, back right up and spin the chariot behind them.
ai-an8:14.10.5_0: They’re like the person who mistakes branches and leaves for heartwood, I say.
ai-an8:14.10.6_0: Some wild people are like that.
ai-an8:14.10.7_0: This is the first defect of a person.
ai-an8:14.11.1_0: Furthermore, the mendicants accuse a mendicant of an offense.
ai-an8:14.11.2_0: But the accused mendicant objects to the accuser:
ai-an8:14.11.3_0: ‘What’s an incompetent fool like you got to say?
ai-an8:14.11.4_0: How on earth could you imagine you’ve got something worth saying!’
ai-an8:14.11.5_0: I say that this person is comparable to the wild colts who, when the trainer says ‘giddyup!’ and spurs and goads them on, jump back, wreck the hub, and break the triple rod.
ai-an8:14.11.6_0: They’re like the person who mistakes branches and leaves for heartwood, I say.
ai-an8:14.11.7_0: Some wild people are like that.
ai-an8:14.11.8_0: This is the second defect of a person.
ai-an8:14.12.1_0: Furthermore, the mendicants accuse a mendicant of an offense.
ai-an8:14.12.2_0: But the accused mendicant retorts to the accuser:
ai-an8:14.12.3_0: ‘You have committed such-and-such an offense. You should make amends for it.’
ai-an8:14.12.4_0: I say that this person is comparable to the wild colts who, when the trainer says ‘giddyup!’ and spurs and goads them on, shake the cart-pole off their thigh and trample it.
ai-an8:14.12.5_0: They’re like the person who mistakes branches and leaves for heartwood, I say.
ai-an8:14.12.6_0: Some wild people are like that.
ai-an8:14.12.7_0: This is the third defect of a person.
ai-an8:14.13.1_0: Furthermore, the mendicants accuse a mendicant of an offense.
ai-an8:14.13.2_0: But the accused mendicant dodges the issue, distracts the discussion with irrelevant points, and displays annoyance, hate, and bitterness.
ai-an8:14.13.3_0: I say that this person is comparable to the wild colts who, when the trainer says ‘giddyup!’ and spurs and goads them on, take a wrong turn, sending the chariot off track.
ai-an8:14.13.4_0: They’re like the person who mistakes branches and leaves for heartwood, I say.
ai-an8:14.13.5_0: Some wild people are like that.
ai-an8:14.13.6_0: This is the fourth defect of a person.
ai-an8:14.14.1_0: Furthermore, the mendicants accuse a mendicant of an offense.
ai-an8:14.14.2_0: But the accused mendicant gesticulates while speaking in the middle of the Saṅgha.
ai-an8:14.14.3_0: I say that this person is comparable to the wild colts who, when the trainer says ‘giddyup!’ and spurs and goads them on, rear up and strike out with their fore-legs.
ai-an8:14.14.4_0: They’re like the person who mistakes branches and leaves for heartwood, I say.
ai-an8:14.14.5_0: Some wild people are like that.
ai-an8:14.14.6_0: This is the fifth defect of a person.
ai-an8:14.15.1_0: Furthermore, the mendicants accuse a mendicant of an offense.
ai-an8:14.15.2_0: But the accused mendicant ignores the Saṅgha and the accusation and, though still guilty of the offense, they go wherever they want.
ai-an8:14.15.3_0: I say that this person is comparable to the trainer.
ai-an8:14.15.4_0: They’re like the person who mistakes branches and leaves for heartwood, I say.
ai-an8:14.15.5_0: Some wild people are like that.
ai-an8:14.15.6_0: This is the sixth defect of a person.
ai-an8:14.16.1_0: Furthermore, the mendicants accuse a mendicant of an offense.
ai-an8:14.16.2_0: But the accused mendicant neither confesses to the offense nor denies it, but frustrates the Saṅgha by staying silent.
ai-an8:14.16.3_0: I say that this person is comparable to the wild colts who, when the trainer says ‘giddyup!’ and spurs and goads them on, don’t step forward or turn back but stand right there still as a post.
ai-an8:14.16.4_0: They’re like the person who mistakes branches and leaves for heartwood, I say.
ai-an8:14.16.5_0: Some wild people are like that.
ai-an8:14.16.6_0: This is the seventh defect of a person.
ai-an8:14.17.1_0: Furthermore, the mendicants accuse a mendicant of an offense.
ai-an8:14.17.2_0: But the accused mendicant says this:
ai-an8:14.17.3_0: ‘Why are you venerables making so much of an issue over me? Now I’ll resign the training and return to a lesser life.’
ai-an8:14.17.4_0: When they have resigned the training, they say:
ai-an8:14.17.6_0: I say that this person is comparable to the wild colts who, when the trainer says ‘giddyup!’ and spurs and goads them on, tuck in their fore-legs and hind-legs, and sit right down on their four legs.
ai-an8:14.17.7_0: They’re like the person who mistakes branches and leaves for heartwood, I say.
ai-an8:14.17.8_0: Some wild people are like that.
ai-an8:14.17.9_0: This is the eighth defect of a person.
ai-an8:14.17.10_0: These are the eight wild people.”

ai-an8:19.1.1_0: At one time the Buddha was staying in Verañja at the root of a neem tree dedicated to Naḷeru.
ai-an8:19.1.2_1: and after approaching and worshipping the Fortunate One, he stood on one side.
ai-an8:19.2.1_0: “Well, Pahārāda, do the demons love the ocean?”
ai-an8:19.2.3_0: “But seeing what incredible and amazing things do the demons love the ocean?”
ai-an8:19.2.4_0: “Sir, seeing eight incredible and amazing things the demons love the ocean.
ai-an8:19.2.5_0: What are the teachings grouped by eight?
ai-an8:19.2.6_0: The ocean gradually slants, slopes, and inclines, with no abrupt precipice.
ai-an8:19.2.7_0: This is the ocean gradually slants, slopes, and inclines, with no abrupt precipice.
ai-an8:19.2.8_0: This is the first thing the demons love about the ocean.
ai-an8:19.3.1_0: Furthermore, the ocean is consistent and doesn’t overflow its boundaries.
ai-an8:19.3.2_0: This is the great ocean, reverend Sir, which is steady, does not go beyond the shoreline.
ai-an8:19.3.3_0: This is the second thing the demons love about the ocean.
ai-an8:19.4.1_0: Furthermore, the ocean does not endure a dead corpse,
ai-an8:19.4.2_0: but quickly carries it to the shore and strands it on the beach.
ai-an8:19.4.4_0: This is the third thing the demons love about the ocean.

ai-an8:30.13.4_0: “Mendicants, I will teach you about eight thoughts. ...
ai-an8:30.13.5_0: And what are the eight thoughts of a great man?
ai-an8:30.13.6_0: This teaching is for those of few wishes, not those of many wishes.
ai-an8:30.13.7_0: It’s for the contented, not those who lack contentment.
ai-an8:30.13.8_0: It’s for the secluded, not those who enjoy company.
ai-an8:30.13.9_0: It’s for the energetic, not the lazy.
ai-an8:30.13.10_0: It’s for the mindful, not the unmindful.
ai-an8:30.13.11_0: It’s for those with immersion, not those without immersion.
ai-an8:30.13.12_0: It’s for the wise, not the witless.
ai-an8:30.13.13_0: It’s for those who don’t enjoy proliferating and don’t like to proliferate, not for those who enjoy proliferating and like to proliferate.
ai-an8:30.14.1_0: ‘This teaching is for those of few wishes, not those of many wishes.’
ai-an8:30.14.2_0: This is what was said, but in regard to what was it said?
ai-an8:30.14.3_0: A mendicant with few wishes doesn’t wish: ‘May they know me as having few wishes!’ When contented, they don’t wish: ‘May they know me as contented!’ When secluded, they don’t wish: ‘May they know me as secluded!’ When energetic, they don’t wish: ‘May they know me as energetic!’ When mindful, they don’t wish: ‘May they know me as mindful!’ When immersed, they don’t wish: ‘May they know me as immersed!’ When wise, they don’t wish: ‘May they know me as wise!’ When not enjoying proliferation, they don’t wish: ‘May they know me as one who doesn’t enjoy proliferating!’
ai-an8:30.14.4_0: ‘This teaching is for those of few wishes, not those of many wishes.’
ai-an8:30.14.5_0: That’s why I said what I said.
ai-an8:30.15.1_0: ‘This teaching is for the contented, not those who lack contentment.’ That’s what I said, but why did I say it?
ai-an8:30.15.2_0: It’s for a mendicant who’s content with any kind of robes, alms-food, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick.
ai-an8:30.15.3_0: ‘This teaching is for the contented, not those who lack contentment.’
ai-an8:30.15.4_0: That’s why I said what I said.
ai-an8:30.16.1_0: ‘This teaching is for the secluded, not those who enjoy company.’ That’s what I said, but why did I say it?
ai-an8:30.16.2_0: It’s for a mendicant who lives secluded. But monks, nuns, laymen, laywomen, rulers and their ministers, founders of religious sects and their disciples go to visit them.
ai-an8:30.16.3_0: With a mind slanting, sloping, and inclining to seclusion, withdrawn, and loving renunciation, that mendicant invariably gives each of them a talk emphasizing the topic of dismissal.
ai-an8:30.16.4_0: ‘This teaching is for the secluded, not those who enjoy company.’
ai-an8:30.16.5_0: That’s why I said what I said.
ai-an8:30.17.1_0: ‘This teaching is for the energetic, not the lazy.’ That’s what I said, but why did I say it?
ai-an8:30.17.2_0: It’s for a mendicant who lives with energy roused up for giving up unskillful qualities and embracing skillful qualities. They’re strong, staunchly vigorous, not slacking off when it comes to developing skillful qualities.
ai-an8:30.17.3_0: ‘This teaching is for the energetic, not the lazy.’
ai-an8:30.17.4_0: That’s why I said what I said.
ai-an8:30.18.1_0: ‘This teaching is for the mindful, not the unmindful.’
ai-an8:30.18.2_0: This is what was said, but in regard to what was it said?
ai-an8:30.18.3_0: It’s when a mendicant is mindful. They have utmost mindfulness and alertness, and can remember and recall what was said and done long ago.
ai-an8:30.18.4_0: ‘This teaching is for the mindful, not the unmindful.’
ai-an8:30.18.5_0: That’s why I said what I said.
ai-an8:30.19.1_0: ‘This teaching is for the secluded, not those with immersion.’
ai-an8:30.19.2_0: This is what was said, but in regard to what was it said?
ai-an8:30.19.3_0: It’s when a mendicant, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, enters and remains in the first absorption ... second absorption ... third absorption ... fourth absorption.
ai-an8:30.19.4_0: ‘This teaching is for the secluded, not those with immersion.’
ai-an8:30.19.5_0: That’s why I said what I said.
ai-an8:30.20.1_0: ‘This teaching is for the witless, not the witless.’
ai-an8:30.20.2_0: This is what was said, but in regard to what was it said?
ai-an8:30.20.3_0: It’s for a mendicant who’s wise. They have the wisdom of arising and passing away which is noble, penetrative, and leads to the complete ending of suffering.
ai-an8:30.20.4_0: ‘This teaching is for the witless, not the witless.’
ai-an8:30.20.5_0: That’s why I said what I said.
ai-an8:30.21.1_0: ‘This teaching is for those who don’t enjoy proliferating and don’t like to proliferate, not for those who enjoy proliferating and like to proliferate.’
ai-an8:30.21.2_0: This is what was said, but in regard to what was it said?
ai-an8:30.21.3_0: It’s for a mendicant whose mind is eager, confident, settled, and decided regarding the cessation of proliferation.
ai-an8:30.21.4_0: ‘This teaching is for those who don’t enjoy proliferating and don’t like to proliferate, not for those who enjoy proliferating and like to proliferate.’
ai-an8:30.21.5_0: That’s what I said, and this is why I said it.”
ai-an8:30.22.1_0: Then Anuruddha stayed the next rainy season residence right there in the land of the Cetīs in the Eastern Bamboo Park.
ai-an8:30.22.2_0: Then Anuruddha, living alone, withdrawn, diligent, keen, and resolute, soon realized the supreme culmination of the spiritual path in this very life. He lived having achieved with his own insight the goal for which gentlemen rightly go forth from the lay life to homelessness.
ai-an8:30.22.3_0: He understood: “Rebirth is ended; the spiritual journey has been completed; what had to be done has been done; there is no return to any state of existence.”
ai-an8:30.22.4_0: And Venerable Anuruddha became one of the perfected.

ai-an8:33.1.1_0: “Mendicants, there are these eight grounds for giving.
ai-an8:33.1.3_0: A person might give a gift out of favoritism or hostility or stupidity or cowardice. Or they give thinking, ‘Giving was practiced by my father and my father’s father. It would not be right for me to abandon this family tradition.’ Or they give thinking, ‘After I’ve given this gift, when my body breaks up, after death, I’ll be reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.’ Or they give thinking, ‘When giving this gift my mind becomes clear, and I become happy and joyful.’ Or they give thinking, ‘This is an adornment and requisite for the mind.’
ai-an8:33.1.4_0: These are the eight grounds for giving.”
ai-an8:34.1.1_0: “Mendicants, when a field has eight factors a seed sown in it is not fruitful or rewarding or productive.
ai-an8:34.1.2_0: What eight factors does it have?
ai-an8:34.1.3_0: It’s when a field has mounds and ditches. It has stones and gravel. It’s salty. It doesn’t have deep furrows. And it’s not equipped with water inlets, water outlets, irrigation channels, and boundaries.
ai-an8:34.1.4_0: When a field has these eight factors a seed sown in it is not fruitful or rewarding or productive.
ai-an8:34.2.1_0: In the same way, when an ascetic or brahmin has eight factors a gift given to them is not very fruitful or beneficial or splendid or bountiful.
ai-an8:34.2.2_0: What eight factors do they have?
ai-an8:34.2.3_0: It’s when someone has wrong view, wrong thought, wrong speech, wrong action, wrong livelihood, wrong effort, wrong mindfulness, and wrong immersion.
ai-an8:34.2.4_0: When an ascetic or brahmin has these eight factors a gift given to them is not very fruitful or beneficial or splendid or bountiful.
ai-an8:34.3.1_0: When a field has eight factors a seed sown in it is very fruitful and rewarding and productive.
ai-an8:34.3.2_0: What eight factors does it have?
ai-an8:34.3.3_0: It’s when a field doesn’t have mounds and ditches. It doesn’t have stones and gravel. It’s not salty. It has deep furrows. And it’s equipped with water inlets, water outlets, irrigation channels, and boundaries.
ai-an8:34.3.4_0: When a field has these eight factors a seed sown in it is very fruitful and rewarding and productive.
ai-an8:34.4.1_0: In the same way, when an ascetic or brahmin has eight factors a gift given to them is very fruitful and beneficial and splendid and bountiful.
ai-an8:34.4.2_0: What eight factors do they have?
ai-an8:34.4.3_0: It’s when some ascetics and brahmins have right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion.
ai-an8:34.4.4_0: When an ascetic or brahmin has these eight factors a gift given to them is very fruitful and beneficial and splendid and bountiful.
ai-an8:34.5.2_0: and the seed sown in it is excellent,
ai-an8:34.5.4_0: the crop of grain will be excellent.

ai-an8:35.1.1_0: “Mendicants, there are these eight rebirths by giving.

ai-an8:35.1.4_0: Whatever they give, they expect something back.

ai-an8:36.1.1_0: “Mendicants, there are these three grounds for making merit.
ai-an8:36.1.3_0: Giving, ethical conduct, and meditation are all grounds for making merit.
ai-an8:36.2.1_0: First, someone has practiced a little giving and ethical conduct as grounds for making merit, but they haven’t got as far as meditation as a ground for making merit.
ai-an8:36.2.2_0: When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn among well-off humans.
ai-an8:36.3.1_0: Next, someone has practiced a moderate amount of giving and ethical conduct as grounds for making merit, but they haven’t got as far as meditation as a ground for making merit.
ai-an8:36.3.2_0: When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn among well-off humans.
ai-an8:36.4.1_0: Next, someone has practiced a lot of giving and ethical conduct as grounds for making merit, but they haven’t got as far as meditation as a ground for making merit.
ai-an8:36.4.2_0: When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in the company of the Gods of the Four Great Kings.

ai-an8:39.1.1_0: “Mendicants, there are these eight kinds of overflowing merit, overflowing goodness. They nurture happiness and are conducive to heaven, ripening in happiness and leading to heaven. They lead to what is likable, desirable, agreeable, to welfare and happiness.
ai-an8:39.1.2_0: What are the teachings grouped by eight?
ai-an8:39.1.3_0: Firstly, a noble disciple has gone for refuge to the Buddha.

ai-an8:39.3.3_0: Mendicants, these five gifts are great, primordial, long-standing, traditional, and ancient. They are uncorrupted, as they have been since the beginning. They’re not being corrupted now nor will they be. Sensible ascetics and brahmins don’t look down on them.
ai-an8:39.3.5_0: Firstly, a noble disciple gives up killing living creatures.
ai-an8:39.3.6_0: By so doing they give to countless sentient beings the gift of freedom from fear, enmity, and ill will.
ai-an8:39.3.7_0: And they themselves also enjoy unlimited freedom from fear, enmity, and ill will.
ai-an8:39.3.8_0: This is the first gift that is a great offering, primordial, long-standing, traditional, and ancient. It is uncorrupted, as it has been since the beginning. It’s not being corrupted now nor will it be. Sensible ascetics and brahmins don’t look down on it.

ai-an8:39.8.1_0: These are the eight kinds of overflowing merit, overflowing goodness. They nurture happiness and are conducive to heaven, ripening in happiness and leading to heaven. They lead to what is likable, desirable, agreeable, to welfare and happiness.”
ai-an8:40.1.1_0: “Mendicants, the killing of living creatures, when cultivated, developed, and practiced, leads to hell, the animal realm, or the ghost realm.
ai-an8:40.1.2_0: The minimum result it leads to for a human being is a short life span.
ai-an8:40.2.2_0: The minimum result it leads to for a human being is loss of wealth.
ai-an8:40.3.1_0: Sexual misconduct, when cultivated, developed, and practiced, leads to hell, the animal realm, or the ghost realm.
ai-an8:40.3.2_0: The minimum result it leads to for a human being is rivalry and enmity.
ai-an8:40.4.1_0: Lying, when cultivated, developed, and practiced, leads to hell, the animal realm, or the ghost realm.
ai-an8:40.4.2_0: The minimum result it leads to for a human being is false accusations.
ai-an8:40.5.1_0: Divisive speech, when cultivated, developed, and practiced, leads to hell, the animal realm, or the ghost realm.
ai-an8:40.5.2_0: The minimum result it leads to for a human being is being divided against friends.
ai-an8:40.6.1_0: Harsh speech, when cultivated, developed, and practiced, leads to hell, the animal realm, or the ghost realm.
ai-an8:40.6.2_0: The minimum result it leads to for a human being is hearing disagreeable things.
ai-an8:40.7.1_0: Talking nonsense, when cultivated, developed, and practiced, leads to hell, the animal realm, or the ghost realm.
ai-an8:40.7.2_0: The minimum result it leads to for a human being is being divided against a human being.
ai-an8:40.8.1_0: Taking alcoholic drinks that cause negligence, when cultivated, developed, and practiced, leads to hell, the animal realm, or the ghost realm.
ai-an8:40.8.2_0: The minimum result it leads to for a human being is madness.”

ai-an8:41.1.2_0: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
ai-an8:41.2.1_0: “Mendicants, the observance of the sabbath with its eight factors is very fruitful and beneficial and splendid and bountiful.
ai-an8:41.2.2_0: And how should it be observed?
ai-an8:41.2.3_0: It’s when a noble disciple reflects:
ai-an8:41.2.4_0: ‘As long as they live, the perfected ones give up killing living creatures, renouncing the rod and the sword. They are scrupulous and kind, and live full of compassion for all living beings.
ai-an8:41.2.5_0: I, too, for this day and night will give up killing living creatures, renouncing the rod and the sword. I’ll be scrupulous and kind, and live full of compassion for all living beings.
ai-an8:41.2.6_0: I will observe the sabbath by doing as the perfected ones do in this respect.’
ai-an8:41.3.1_0: ‘As long as they live, the perfected ones give up stealing. They take only what’s given, and expect only what’s given. They keep themselves clean by not thieving.
ai-an8:41.3.2_0: I, too, for this day and night will give up stealing. I’ll take only what’s given, and expect only what’s given. I’ll keep myself clean by not thieving.
ai-an8:41.3.3_0: I will observe the sabbath by doing as the perfected ones do in this respect.’
ai-an8:41.4.1_0: ‘As long as they live, the perfected ones give up unchastity. They are celibate, set apart, avoiding the common practice of sex.
ai-an8:41.4.2_0: I, too, for this day and night will give up unchastity. I will be celibate, set apart, avoiding the common practice of sex.
ai-an8:41.4.3_0: I will observe the sabbath by doing as the perfected ones do in this respect.’
ai-an8:41.5.1_0: ‘As long as they live, the perfected ones give up lying. They speak the truth and stick to the truth. They’re honest and trustworthy, and don’t trick the world with their words.
ai-an8:41.5.2_0: I, too, for this day and night will give up lying. I’ll speak the truth and stick to the truth. I’ll be honest and trustworthy, and won’t trick the world with my words.
ai-an8:41.5.3_0: I will observe the sabbath by doing as the perfected ones do in this respect.’
ai-an8:41.6.1_0: ‘As long as they live, the perfected ones give up alcoholic drinks that cause negligence.
ai-an8:41.6.2_0: I, too, for this day and night will give up alcoholic drinks that cause negligence.
ai-an8:41.6.3_0: I will observe the sabbath by doing as the perfected ones do in this respect.’
ai-an8:41.7.1_0: ‘As long as they live, the perfected ones eat in one part of the day, abstaining from eating at night and from food at the wrong time.
ai-an8:41.7.2_0: I, too, for this day and night will eat in one part of the day, abstaining from eating at night and food at the wrong time.
ai-an8:41.7.3_0: I will observe the sabbath by doing as the perfected ones do in this respect.’
ai-an8:41.8.1_0: ‘As long as they live, the perfected ones give up dancing, singing, music, and seeing shows; and beautifying and adorning themselves with garlands, fragrance, and makeup.
ai-an8:41.8.2_0: I, too, for this day and night will give up dancing, singing, music, and seeing shows; and beautifying and adorning myself with garlands, fragrance, and makeup.
ai-an8:41.8.3_0: I will observe the sabbath by doing as the perfected ones do in this respect.’
ai-an8:41.9.1_0: ‘As long as they live, the perfected ones give up high and luxurious beds. They sleep in a low place, either a small bed or a straw mat.
ai-an8:41.9.2_0: I, too, for this day and night will give up high and luxurious beds. I’ll sleep in a low place, either a small bed or a straw mat.
ai-an8:41.9.3_0: I will observe the sabbath by doing as the perfected ones do in this respect.’
ai-an8:41.10.1_0: The observance of the sabbath with its eight factors in this way is very fruitful and beneficial and splendid and bountiful.”

ai-an8:51.20.1_1: and after approaching he said this to Mahāpajāpatī Gotamī:
ai-an8:51.21.1_0: “If you accept eight important principles, Gotami, that will be your full ordination.”
ai-an8:51.22.1_0: A nun, even if she has been ordained for a hundred years, should bow down to a monk who was ordained that very day. She should rise up for him, greet him with joined palms, and observe proper etiquette toward him.
ai-an8:51.22.2_0: This rule too is to be honored and respected all one’s life, and is not to be breached.
ai-an8:51.23.1_0: From today onwards, nuns may not correct monks, but monks may correct nuns.

ai-an8:51.23.3_0: If you accept these eight principles of respect, that will be your ordination.”
ai-an8:51.24.1_0: She replied, “Just as a young woman or man—someone fond of adornments, who had just washed her hair—would receive a garland of lotuses, a garland of sandan flowers, or a garland of jasmine with both hands and place it on her head,
ai-an8:51.24.2_0: In the same way, sir, I accept these eight principles of respect as not to be transgressed so long as life lasts.”
ai-an8:51.25.1_0: Then Venerable Ānanda went up to the Buddha,
ai-an8:51.25.1_2: After the meal, on his return from alms-round, he went to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and told him what had happened.
ai-an8:51.25.2_0: “Sir, Mahāpajāpatī Gotamī accepts these eight principles of respect. He should not be transgressed for life.”
ai-an8:51.26.1_0: “Ānanda, if women had not been allowed to go forth on this spiritual path made known by the Buddha, the spiritual life would have lasted a long time—the true Teaching would have lasted a thousand years.
ai-an8:51.26.2_0: But since they have gained the going forth, now the spiritual life will not last long.
ai-an8:51.26.3_0: now the true Teaching will only last five hundred years.
ai-an8:51.27.1_0: Just as families with many women and few men are easily robbed by thieves,
ai-an8:51.27.2_0: In the same way, the spiritual life does not last long in a teaching and training where females gain the going forth.
ai-an8:51.28.1_0: It’s like a field full of rice. Once the disease called ‘white bones’ attacks, it doesn’t last long.
ai-an8:51.28.2_0: In the same way, the spiritual life does not last long in a teaching and training where females gain the going forth.
ai-an8:51.29.1_0: Just as a ripe field of sugarcane attacked by red rot won’t last long,
ai-an8:51.29.2_0: In the same way, the spiritual life does not last long in a teaching and training where females gain the going forth.
ai-an8:51.30.1_0: As a man might build a dyke around a large lake as a precaution against the water overflowing,
ai-an8:51.30.2_0: so too, have I, as a safeguard, laid down the eight important principles, not to be breached for life.”
ai-an8:52.1.1_0: At one time the Buddha was staying near Vesālī, at the Great Wood, in the hall with the peaked roof.
ai-an8:52.1.2_0: Then Venerable Ānanda went up to the Buddha,
ai-an8:52.1.2_2: After the meal, on his return from alms-round, he went to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and told him what had happened.
ai-an8:52.1.3_0: “Sir, how many qualities should a monk have to be agreed on as an adviser for nuns?”
ai-an8:52.2.1_0: “Ānanda, a monk with eight qualities may be agreed on as an adviser for nuns.
ai-an8:52.2.3_0: It’s when a mendicant is ethical, restrained in the code of conduct, with good behavior and supporters. Seeing danger in the slightest fault, they keep the rules they’ve undertaken.
ai-an8:52.2.5_0: He has properly learned both Monastic Codes in detail; he has well analyzed them, thoroughly mastered them, and well investigated them, both in terms of the rules and their detailed exposition.
ai-an8:52.2.6_0: They’re a good speaker. Their voice is polished, clear, articulate, and expresses the meaning.
ai-an8:52.2.7_0: They’re able to educate, encourage, fire up, and inspire the Saṅgha of nuns with a Dhamma talk.
ai-an8:52.2.8_0: He is generally liked by and pleasing to the nuns.
ai-an8:52.2.9_0: He has never committed a heavy offense against a Buddhist nun.
ai-an8:52.2.10_0: He has either twenty Rains Retreats or more than twenty Rains Retreats.
ai-an8:52.2.11_0: A monk with these eight qualities may be agreed on as an adviser for nuns.”
ai-an8:53.1.1_0: At one time the Buddha was staying near Vesālī, at the Great Wood, in the hall with the peaked roof.

ai-an8:53.3.8_0: lead to being energetic, not to indolence,

ai-an8:53.3.10_0: You should definitely bear in mind that these things are

ai-an8:54.1.1_0: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Koliyans, where they have a town named Kakkarapatta.
ai-an8:54.1.2_0: Then Dīghajāṇu the Koliyan went to the Fortunate One,
ai-an8:54.1.2_2: He bowed, sat down to one side, and said to the Buddha:
ai-an8:54.1.3_0: “Sir, we are laypeople who enjoy sensual pleasures and living at home with our children. We use sandalwood imported from Kāsi, we wear garlands, perfumes, and makeup, and we accept gold and money.
ai-an8:54.1.4_0: May the Buddha please teach us the Dhamma in a way that leads to our welfare and happiness in this life and in future lives.”
ai-an8:54.2.1_0: “Byagghapajja, these four things lead to the welfare and happiness of a gentleman in this life.
ai-an8:54.2.2_0: What are the teachings grouped by four?
ai-an8:54.2.3_0: Accomplishment in initiative, protection, good friendship, and balanced finances.
ai-an8:54.2.4_0: And what is accomplishment in initiative?
ai-an8:54.2.5_0: It’s when a gentleman earns a living by means such as
ai-an8:54.2.6_0: farming, trade, raising cattle, archery, government service, or one of the professions.
ai-an8:54.2.7_0: He understands how to go about these things in order to complete and organize the work.
ai-an8:54.2.8_0: This is called accomplishment in initiative.
ai-an8:54.3.1_0: And what is accomplishment in protection?
ai-an8:54.3.2_0: It’s when a gentleman owns legitimate wealth that he has earned by his own efforts and initiative, built up with his own hands, gathered by the sweat of the brow.
ai-an8:54.3.3_0: He ensures it is guarded and protected, thinking:
ai-an8:54.3.4_0: ‘How can these kings not take my wealth from being taken by rulers or bandits, consumed by fire, swept away by flood, or taken by unloved heirs?’
ai-an8:54.3.5_0: This is called accomplishment in protection.
ai-an8:54.4.1_0: And what is accomplishment in good friendship?
ai-an8:54.4.2_0: It’s when a gentleman resides in a town or village. And in that place there are householders or their children who may be young or old, but are mature in conduct, accomplished in faith, ethics, generosity, and wisdom.
ai-an8:54.4.2_1: And the ethical conduct of faith, ethics, learning, generosity, and wisdom.
ai-an8:54.4.3_0: This is called accomplishment in good friendship.
ai-an8:54.5.1_0: And what is accomplishment in balanced finances?
ai-an8:54.5.2_0: It’s when a gentleman, knowing his income and expenditure, balances his finances, being neither too extravagant nor too frugal.
ai-an8:54.5.2_1: ‘This is how I’ll occupy my mind.’
ai-an8:54.5.3_0: It’s like an appraiser or their apprentice who, holding up the scales, knows that it’s low by this.
ai-an8:54.5.3_1: it was said by this much left over.

ai-an8:54.5.4_1: ‘This is how I’ll occupy my mind.’

ai-an8:54.5.8_0: This is called accomplishment in balanced finances.

ai-an8:63.1.6_0: “Well then, mendicant, you should train like this:
ai-an8:63.1.7_0: ‘My mind will be steady and well settled internally. And bad, unskillful qualities that have arisen will not occupy my mind.’

ai-an8:63.2.2_0: ‘I will develop the heart’s release by love. I’ll cultivate it, make it my vehicle and my basis, keep it up, consolidate it, and properly implement it.’

ai-an8:63.11.1_0: When that mendicant had been given this advice by the Buddha, he got up from his seat, bowed, and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on his right, before leaving.
ai-an8:63.11.2_0: Then that mendicant, living alone, withdrawn, diligent, keen, and resolute, soon realized the supreme end of the spiritual path in this very life. He lived having achieved with his own insight the goal for which gentlemen rightly go forth from the lay life to homelessness.
ai-an8:63.11.3_0: He understood: “Rebirth is ended; the spiritual journey has been completed; what had to be done has been done; there is no return to any state of existence.”
ai-an8:63.11.4_0: And that mendicant became one of the perfected.

ai-an8:65.1.1_0: “Mendicants, there are these eight dimensions of mastery.
ai-an8:65.1.3_0: Perceiving form internally, someone sees visions externally, limited, both pretty and ugly.
ai-an8:65.1.4_0: Mastering them, they perceive: ‘I know and see.’
ai-an8:65.1.5_0: This is the first dimension of mastery.
ai-an8:65.2.1_0: Perceiving form internally, someone sees visions externally, limitless, both pretty and ugly.
ai-an8:65.2.2_0: Mastering them, they perceive: ‘I know and see.’
ai-an8:65.2.3_0: This is the second means of (mind) mastery.

ai-an8:70.14.2_0: What are the teachings grouped by eight?
ai-an8:70.14.3_0: This great earth is grounded in the water,
ai-an8:70.14.3_3: There comes a time, Ānanda, when great winds blow,

ai-an8:70.15.1_0: Furthermore, there is an ascetic or brahmin with psychic power who has achieved mastery of the mind, or a god who is mighty and powerful.

ai-an8:70.15.1_2: They’ve developed a limited perception of earth and a limitless perception of water. They make the earth shake and rock and tremble.

ai-an8:70.17.2_0: This is the fourth cause and reason for a great earthquake.

ai-an8:70.20.1_0: Furthermore, when the Realized One, mindful and aware, surrenders the life force, the earth shakes and rocks and trembles.
ai-an8:70.20.2_0: This is the seventh cause and reason for a great earthquake.
ai-an8:70.21.1_0: Furthermore, when the Realized One becomes fully extinguished through the natural principle of extinguishment, without anything left over, the earth shakes and rocks and trembles.
ai-an8:70.21.2_0: This is the eighth cause and reason for a great earthquake.
ai-an8:70.21.3_0: These are the eight causes and reasons for a great earthquake.”

ai-an8:74.1.1_0: At one time the Buddha was staying at Nādika in the brick house.
ai-an8:74.1.2_0: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants:
ai-an8:74.1.3_0: “Mendicants, when mindfulness of death is developed and cultivated it’s very fruitful and beneficial. It culminates in the deathless and ends with the deathless.
ai-an8:74.2.1_0: And how is mindfulness of death developed and cultivated to be very fruitful and beneficial, to culminate in the deathless and end with the deathless?
ai-an8:74.2.2_0: As day passes by and night draws close, a mendicant reflects:
ai-an8:74.2.4_0: A snake might bite me, or a scorpion or centipede might sting me.
ai-an8:74.2.5_0: And if I died from that it would stop my practice.
ai-an8:74.2.6_0: Or I might stumble off a cliff, or get food poisoning, or suffer a disturbance of bile, phlegm, or piercing winds. Or I might be attacked by humans or non-humans.
ai-an8:74.2.7_0: And if I died from that it would stop my practice. ’
ai-an8:74.2.9_0: ‘Are there any bad, unskillful qualities that I haven’t given up, which might be an obstacle to me if I die tonight?’
ai-an8:74.3.1_0: Suppose that, upon checking, a mendicant knows that
ai-an8:74.3.2_0: there are such bad, unskillful qualities. Then in order to give them up they should apply outstanding enthusiasm, effort, zeal, vigor, perseverance, mindfulness, and situational awareness.
ai-an8:74.4.1_0: Suppose your clothes or head were on fire. In order to extinguish it, you’d apply intense enthusiasm, effort, zeal, vigor, perseverance, mindfulness, and situational awareness.
ai-an8:74.4.2_0: In the same way, in order to give up those bad, unskillful qualities, that mendicant should apply outstanding enthusiasm ...
ai-an8:74.5.1_0: But suppose that, upon checking, a mendicant knows that
ai-an8:74.5.2_0: there are no such bad, unskillful qualities. Then that mendicant should meditate with rapture and joy, training day and night in skillful qualities.
ai-an8:74.6.1_0: Or else, as night passes by and day draws close, a mendicant reflects:
ai-an8:74.6.3_0: A snake might bite me, or a scorpion or centipede might sting me.
ai-an8:74.6.4_0: And if I died from that it would stop my practice.
ai-an8:74.6.5_0: Or I might stumble off a cliff, or get food poisoning, or suffer a disturbance of bile, phlegm, or piercing winds. Or I might be attacked by humans or non-humans.
ai-an8:74.6.6_0: And if I died from that it would stop my practice. ’
ai-an8:74.6.8_0: ‘Are there any bad, unskillful qualities that I haven’t given up, which might be an obstacle to me if I die tonight?’
ai-an8:74.7.1_0: Suppose that, upon checking, a mendicant knows that
ai-an8:74.7.2_0: there are such bad, unskillful qualities. Then in order to give them up they should apply outstanding enthusiasm, effort, zeal, vigor, perseverance, mindfulness, and situational awareness.
ai-an8:74.8.1_0: Suppose your clothes or head were on fire. In order to extinguish it, you’d apply intense enthusiasm, effort, zeal, vigor, perseverance, mindfulness, and situational awareness.
ai-an8:74.8.2_0: In the same way, in order to give up those bad, unskillful qualities, that mendicant should apply outstanding enthusiasm ...
ai-an8:74.9.1_0: But suppose that, upon checking, a mendicant knows that
ai-an8:74.9.2_0: there are no such bad, unskillful qualities. Then that mendicant should meditate with rapture and joy, training day and night in skillful qualities.
ai-an8:74.9.3_0: Mindfulness of death, when developed and cultivated in this way, is very fruitful and beneficial. It culminates in the deathless and ends with the deathless.”

ai-an8:76.1.3_0: Accomplishment in initiative, protection, good friendship, and balanced finances. And accomplishment in faith, ethics, generosity, and wisdom.
ai-an8:76.1.4_0: And what is accomplishment in initiative?
ai-an8:76.1.5_0: A gentleman may earn a living by means such as
ai-an8:76.1.6_0: farming, trade, raising cattle, archery, government service, or one of the professions.
ai-an8:76.1.7_0: He understands how to go about these things in order to complete and organize the work.
ai-an8:76.1.8_0: This is called accomplishment in initiative.
ai-an8:76.2.1_0: And what is accomplishment in protection?
ai-an8:76.2.2_0: It’s when a gentleman owns legitimate wealth that he has earned by his own efforts and initiative, built up with his own hands, gathered by the sweat of the brow. He ensures it is guarded and protected, thinking:
ai-an8:76.2.3_0: ‘How can I prevent my wealth from being taken by rulers or bandits, consumed by fire, swept away by flood, or taken by unloved heirs?’
ai-an8:76.2.4_0: This is called accomplishment in protection.
ai-an8:76.3.1_0: And what is accomplishment in good friendship?
ai-an8:76.3.2_0: It’s when a gentleman resides in a town or village. And in that place there are householders or their children who may be young or old, but are mature in conduct, accomplished in faith, ethics, generosity, and wisdom. He associates with them, converses and engages in discussion.
ai-an8:76.3.2_1: And the ethical conduct of faith, ethics, learning, generosity, and wisdom.
ai-an8:76.3.3_0: This is called accomplishment in good friendship.
ai-an8:76.4.1_0: And what is accomplishment in balanced finances?
ai-an8:76.4.2_0: It’s when a gentleman, knowing his income and expenditure, balances his finances, being neither too extravagant nor too frugal.
ai-an8:76.4.2_1: ‘This is how I’ll occupy my mind.’
ai-an8:76.4.3_0: It’s like an appraiser or their apprentice who, holding up the scales, knows that it’s low by this.
ai-an8:76.4.3_1: it was said by this much left over.
ai-an8:76.4.4_0: In the same way, a gentleman, knowing his income and expenditure, balances his finances, being neither too extravagant nor too frugal.
ai-an8:76.4.4_1: ‘This is how I’ll occupy my mind.’
ai-an8:76.4.5_0: If a gentleman has little income but an opulent life, people will say: ‘This is an obvious way of living beings.’
ai-an8:76.4.6_0: If a gentleman has a large income but a spartan life, people will say:
ai-an8:76.4.6_1: ‘This gentleman is starving themselves to death!’
ai-an8:76.4.7_0: But a gentleman, knowing his income and expenditure, leads a balanced life, neither too extravagant nor too frugal,
ai-an8:76.4.7_1: ‘This is how I’ll occupy my mind.’
ai-an8:76.4.8_0: This is called accomplishment in balanced finances.
ai-an8:76.5.1_0: And what is accomplishment in faith?
ai-an8:76.5.2_0: It’s when a gentleman has faith in the Realized One’s awakening:
ai-an8:76.5.3_0: ‘That Blessed One is perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those who wish to train, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.’
ai-an8:76.5.4_0: This is called accomplishment in faith.
ai-an8:76.6.1_0: And what is accomplishment in ethics?
ai-an8:76.6.2_0: It’s when a gentleman doesn’t kill living creatures, steal, commit sexual misconduct, lie, or use alcoholic drinks that cause negligence.
ai-an8:76.6.2_1: refrains from liquors, wines, or intoxicants which cause heedlessness.
ai-an8:76.6.3_0: This is called accomplishment in ethics.
ai-an8:76.7.1_0: And what is accomplishment in generosity?
ai-an8:76.7.2_0: It’s when a gentleman lives at home rid of the stain of stinginess, freely generous, open-handed, loving to let go, committed to charity, loving to give and to share.
ai-an8:76.7.2_1: bound to help those who ask, delighting in the distribution of gifts.
ai-an8:76.7.3_0: This is called accomplishment in generosity.
ai-an8:76.8.1_0: And what is accomplishment in wisdom?
ai-an8:76.8.2_0: It’s when a gentleman is wise. He has the wisdom of arising and passing away which is noble, penetrative, and leads to the complete ending of suffering.
ai-an8:76.8.3_0: This is called accomplishment in wisdom.

ai-an8:76.12.4_0: to lead to happiness in both spheres,
ai-an8:76.13.1_0: welfare and benefit in this life,
ai-an8:76.13.3_0: This is how, for a householder,

ai-an8:77.2.1_0: “Reverends, these eight people are found in the world.
ai-an8:77.2.2_0: What are the teachings grouped by eight?
ai-an8:77.2.3_0: First, when a mendicant stays secluded, living independently, a desire arises for material possessions.
ai-an8:77.2.4_0: They try hard, strive, and make an effort to get them.
ai-an8:77.2.5_0: But material possessions don’t come to them.
ai-an8:77.2.6_0: And so they sorrow and wail and lament, beating their breast and falling into confusion because they don’t get those material possessions.
ai-an8:77.2.7_0: This is called a mendicant who lives desiring material possessions. They try hard, strive, and make an effort to get them. But when possessions don’t come to them, they sorrow and lament. They’ve fallen from the true teaching.

ai-an8:77.3.4_0: And so they become indulgent and fall into negligence regarding those material possessions.

ai-an8:79.1.1_0: “These eight things lead to the decline of a mendicant trainee.
ai-an8:79.1.2_0: What are the teachings grouped by eight?
ai-an8:79.1.3_0: They relish work, talk, sleep, and company. They don’t guard the sense doors and they eat too much. They relish closeness and proliferation.
ai-an8:79.1.4_0: These eight things lead to the decline of a mendicant trainee.
ai-an8:79.2.1_0: These eight things don’t lead to the decline of a mendicant trainee.
ai-an8:79.2.2_0: What are the teachings grouped by eight?
ai-an8:79.2.3_0: They don’t relish work, talk, sleep, and company. They guard the sense doors, and they don’t eat too much. They don’t relish closeness and proliferation.
ai-an8:79.2.4_0: These eight things don’t lead to the decline of a mendicant trainee.”
ai-an8:80.1.1_0: “Mendicants, there are eight grounds for laziness.
ai-an8:80.1.3_0: Firstly, a mendicant has some work to do.
ai-an8:80.1.5_1: But while doing it my body will get tired.
ai-an8:80.1.5_2: Lying down would be good for me. I’d better have a lie down.’
ai-an8:80.1.6_0: They lie down, and don’t rouse energy for attaining the unattained, achieving the unachieved, and realizing the unrealized.
ai-an8:80.1.7_0: This is the first ground for laziness.
ai-an8:80.2.1_0: Furthermore, a mendicant has done some work.
ai-an8:80.2.3_0: ‘I’ve done some work. But while working my body got tired. I’d better have a lie down.’
ai-an8:80.2.4_0: They lie down, and don’t rouse energy for attaining the unattained, achieving the unachieved, and realizing the unrealized.
ai-an8:80.2.5_0: This is the second ground for laziness.
ai-an8:80.3.1_0: Furthermore, a mendicant has to go on a journey.

ai-an8:80.3.3_1: But while walking my body will get tired.
ai-an8:80.3.3_2: Lying down would be good for me. I’d better have a lie down.’
ai-an8:80.3.4_0: They lie down, and don’t rouse energy for attaining the unattained, achieving the unachieved, and realizing the unrealized.
ai-an8:80.3.5_0: This is the third ground for laziness.

ai-an8:80.4.4_0: They lie down, and don’t rouse energy for attaining the unattained, achieving the unachieved, and realizing the unrealized.
ai-an8:80.4.5_0: This is the fourth ground for laziness.
